data.title: Undo after external modification does not turn editor dirty
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. have a file open, not dirty
2. change it externally
3. ensure the update happened in the opened editor
4. press undo
=> file should be dirty but is not
5. press redo
=> file should be marked as saved again

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (8b942faafb2d1bee6fd6a346853548d528c7eb5a, 2017-08-31T07:27:43.804Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.16.0
project-manager|ale|0.20.0
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
gitlens|eam|4.4.3
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
prettier-vscode|esb|0.23.1
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
vscode-stylefmt|mrm|2.5.0
atom-keybindings|ms-|3.0.1
vetur|oct|0.9.5
stylelint|shi|0.28.0
vscode-todo-highlight|way|0.5.9
vscode-jumpy|wma|0.3.1

---

Steps to Reproduce:

This is a weird one. I have defined the following custom snippet for Emmet:

`"mrgstart": "@include margin-start(${1:value});",`

When I type `mrg`, the snippet is not shown. It appears only when I type `mrgs`.

If I rename the snippet to `abcstart`, then it is properly shown when I type `abc`.

😵

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: SCM Inline actions are broken
Motivate extensions to upgrade to MarkdownString
data.body: We will disable command-links in the (deprecated) `MarkedString` and extension should use the new `MarkdownString` for command-links. **Background** When using markdown-formatted content, VS Code supports "links" that invoke a command, like so: `[Hello](command:myExt.myCommand)`. This is a powerful feature but has a security concern: With a carefully crafted document and an extension that creates a markdown-string from that content users can be tricked into clicking on what appears to be a link but actually executed a command. Consider the following sample: * I happen to know that you use an extension that includes potential dangers commands, e.g. running arbitrary commands in a shell * I make you use my library file that contains a jsdoc-comment invoking such a command via a command-link * While coding you get a hover saying "click here for more info" which in reality runs a command To tackle this, we ask extensions to identify their markdown contents as trusted or not. E.g. TypeScript will say it don't trust markdown contents because it doesn't generate it, it just forwards. Other extensions, esp. those that generate command-links on purpose will mark their contents as trusted. To support that we have introduced a new type, `MarkdownString`. The `MarkdownString` can be used wherever the `MarkedString` can be used and when constructing it, you can say if you trust the contents, e.g. ```ts // trusted const md = new MarkdownString('[My Cool Feature](command:myTrustedContents)') md.isTrusted = true; // not trusted new MarkdownString(forgeinContentsLikeJsDoc) ```

indent-rainbow|ode|0.6.1
vscode-code-outline|pat|0.0.8
material-icon-theme|PKi|2.2.0
open-in-browser|tec|1.1.0
python|tht|0.2.3
nodejs-extension-pack|wad|0.1.9
better-align|wwm|1.1.6
JavaScriptSnippets|xab|1.4.1
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Add a new python file that print text in output code:
```
for i in range(1, 4000):
  print(i, "random chars text pdpofspodispdsps di sdpofsdpois dpifpsdi psdoipiofsdp")

print("You reach the end!")

```
2. Run code and check the output code folder
3. In output code only the first 2653 rows are shown ("You reach the end!" not ) exiting with code=null.
4. Reducing then number of rows (2500) everything is ok (("You reach the end!" is visible) exiting with code=0.
5. If I run the code in terminal everything is ok.
6. Maybe is there a buffer limit?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9415177/29914333-6ff9893a-8e38-11e7-86e6-7bc77ddd7230.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: changed limitResultCount to Number.MAX_VALUE for findMatches
data.body:
findMatches now has a much higher limit of things it will match to.
this fixed #7201 
But may cause issues in searching exceedingly large files with a "bad search"  

such as searching for "s" in a 400,000 line file... with each line containing 6,000  s characters

data.title: git dirty/clean sign is not updated correctly
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.15.1 - OS Version: macOS 10.12.6 Steps to Reproduce: 1. In terminal, make a directory called "`test`", and make it a git repo by "`git init`". 2. Open this directory in VSCode, by command "`code .`" 3. Create a file "test.txt", and type something. 4. In terminal, git add and git commit. 5. The git symbol at the down-left corner is "master", not "master*". It is correct. 6. Now, type another line into "test.txt". The green strip at the line number indicates it is a new insertion. 7. Now, the git symbol at the down-left corner is "master", not "master*". 8. Git add. 9. Now, the git symbol at the down-left corner is still "master", not "master*". Besides, I hope there is a "force update" option. Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Settings.json option to never show OPEN EDITORS in the file explorer
Color picker: when user start changing color the picker should not easily close
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Hover over a CSS color and the color picker shows up, then move away and the picker goes away which is fine. 
2. Again do an hover over a CSS color again and this time start changing the color and if you have the misfortune of falling outside of the picker area, you lose the original color and your file is now dirty. The only way back is to do an undo (ctrl+z). It happened to me so many times that I slipped outside and lost my original color, the picker is just so small (the size is not the real culprit though) and it's so easy to fall outside.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Proposition:
I would rather argue that if the user starts changing the color, then it's most probably he wants to stay in the picker until he decides that the color is acceptable (or not by clicking back on the original color). If you try Chrome for example, the picker stays open until you click away. I think this could be a better approach, and/or add a "x" on the top corner... but please only implement this behavior **after** the user starts changing the color.
![2017-08-31_00-02-11](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/643976/29905969-af19c4e4-8ddf-11e7-8efc-15ce288c1251.gif)

data.title: Breakpoints for uncaught exceptions do not get triggered for extension development
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:15:57.756Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
ActiveFileInStatusBar|Ros|1.0.3
find-word-at-cursor|mks|1.8.0
code-spell-checker|str|1.3.8
---

I'm assuming that when "Uncaught Exceptions" is checked under "Breakpoints" in the debug view, it will cause a breakpoint to get automatically set and execution will stop when an uncaught exception is encountered so that the developer can debug the issue.

That's not the behavior I'm observing. Instead, I see this in the Extension Development Host:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4027731/29905445-ada4f690-8dc3-11e7-9ba5-a964621ae739.png)

...and no breakpoint is set in the VS Code window where the source code is opened.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use `yo code` to generate an extension.
1. Open the extension in VS Code
1. Add bad code some where or throw an error
1. Run the extension with F5
1. Call the extension with `extension.sayHello`
1. No breakpoint gets triggered even though "Uncaught Exceptions" is checked (by default)

data.title: SVG with long lines causes horizontal scrolling to jump around
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (34cc9f2209be766d5be30a6ecdbb41f5e81fd56b, 2017-08-30T05:23:44.557Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16278
---

This is a very strange one. It isn't a requirement that the svg be on all 1 line for it to jump around, but that is the easiest way to reproduce it reliably.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an svg file all collapsed to a single line of code (see svg below)
2. :bug: Pressing end to jump to the end of the line, jumps to the end and then back to the start (press end 1 more time and it will work)
3. :bug: Using the arrow keys from either the start or end, will keep causing it to jump to the beginning of the line

Here is the svg in question -- it isn't always reproducible, but this svg seems to cause it all the time.

```svg
<svg xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:cc="http://creativecommons.org/ns#" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:svg="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:sodipodi="http://sodipodi.sourceforge.net/DTD/sodipodi-0.dtd" xmlns:inkscape="http://www.inkscape.org/namespaces/inkscape" version="1.1" x="0px" y="0px" viewBox="0 0 100 125"><g transform="translate(0,-952.36215)"><path style="font-size:medium;font-style:normal;font-variant:normal;font-weight:normal;font-stretch:normal;text-indent:0;text-align:start;text-decoration:none;line-height:normal;letter-spacing:normal;word-spacing:normal;text-transform:none;direction:ltr;block-progression:tb;writing-mode:lr-tb;text-anchor:start;baseline-shift:baseline;opacity:1;color:#000000;fill:#000000;fill-opacity:1;stroke:none;stroke-width:3.99999881000000010;marker:none;visibility:visible;display:inline;overflow:visible;enable-background:accumulate;font-family:Sans;-inkscape-font-specification:Sans" d="M 18 25 C 15.818579 25 14 26.81858 14 29 L 14 37 C 14 39.18142 15.818579 41 18 41 L 18 71 C 18 73.1814 19.818594 75 22 75 L 78 75 C 80.181406 75 82 73.1814 82 71 L 82 41 C 84.181421 41 86 39.18142 86 37 L 86 29 C 86 26.81858 84.181421 25 82 25 L 18 25 z M 18 29 L 82 29 L 82 37 L 18 37 L 18 29 z M 22 41 L 78 41 L 78 71 L 22 71 L 22 41 z M 42.8125 46 A 2.0021961 2.0021961 0 1 0 43 50 L 57 50 A 2.0001994 2.0001994 0 1 0 57 46 L 43 46 A 2.0001994 2.0001994 0 0 0 42.8125 46 z " transform="translate(0,952.36215)"/></g><text x="0" y="115" fill="#000000" font-size="5px" font-weight="bold" font-family="'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial-Unicode, Arial, Sans-serif">Created by emma mitchell</text><text x="0" y="120" fill="#000000" font-size="5px" font-weight="bold" font-family="'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial-Unicode, Arial, Sans-serif">from the Noun Project</text></svg>
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [Suggestion] Let zen mode show all opened files in the top tab
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0-Insiders
- OS Version: Win10

If I want to switch to another opened file in zen mode, now I have to :
1. Quit zen mode
2. Switch to another file
3. Enter zen mode again

And actually there is lots of space in the top bar of zen mode.

So it may be more convinient if there are all opened files in the top tab of zen mode.

data.title: Auto-reload of files sucks

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.3
csharp|ms-|1.12.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. spend an hour editing a file and save it
2. accidentally clobber that file on disk by copying over it 
3. Notice that VS code cleverly automatically reloads the bad file losing all your work.
4. Even File->Revert command does nothing.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

So it would be great if at least you could make it configurable whether to automatically reload files that were changed on disk or NOT.  (like VS does).  Thanks.  Twice now I've lost hours of work due to this "feature".

I thought this was previously forbidden?

data.title: Explore improving UX / API for refactorings
data.body:
Refactoring like `extract method` don't seem like a great fit for the code actions or any other API that VSCode offers. This issue tracks an investigation of what a better ux/api for refactorings could look like

**Problems / Background Info**

- @Gama11 makes some very good points about why refactorings don't seem to fit well with the current code action model: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/33241#issuecomment-326003385

- No way to configure a keybinding for specific code actions / refactoring: #33049

- No feedback on why a refactoring is not available: #33501


Any other problems you've noticed or thoughts on refactoring support?

data.title: CSS Emmet Completion: Cannot read property 'filterText' of undefined
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (34cc9f2209be766d5be30a6ecdbb41f5e81fd56b, 2017-08-30T05:11:42.435Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In a css file:
```css
body {
    background: rgba(2, 173, 2, 0.82) !important;
    |
}
```


2. Place cursor at `|` and type `m:`

**bug**

```
shell.ts:419 Cannot read property 'filterText' of undefined: TypeError: Cannot read property 'filterText' of undefined
	at Object.doComplete (/Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/emmet/node_modules/vscode-emmet-helper/out/emmetHelper.js:102:43)
	at noiseCheckPromise.then.noise (/Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/emmet/out/defaultCompletionProvider.js:50:48)
	at <anonymous>
```

data.title: [folding] unfold when typing on first line

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This might be known or tracked somewhere else, but I don't see it called out explicitly anywhere...

- Fold a region of code
- Put the cursor at the end of the folded line
- Press enter and type
  - The typed stuff is visible 
- Once I stop typing for a second, the typed stuff disappears and is under the fold

It seems like pressing enter at the end of a folded line should either unfold, or add a newline after the folded section.

![aug-30-2017 16-21-41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/323878/29899292-59ce8744-8d9f-11e7-8392-e2156ce91020.gif)

data.title: Terminal panel stays maximized when editor is split horizontally
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1 Portable (also 1.15.0)
- OS Version: Windows 10

After being maximized, the terminal panel does not restore to the previous size when the editor is split horizontally, when the editors are stacked on top of each other.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open two editors, split vertically (stacked on top of each other).
2. Maximize panel with the button or the command.
3. Click on the restore button. Nothing happens.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Error in 64bit studio Code unable to find Python.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
typings-installer|ben|0.2.0
npm-intellisense|chr|1.3.0
python|don|0.7.0
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.0
vscode-npm|fkn|3.3.0
tfx-toolkit|har|0.1.0
vscode-tfs|iva|0.6.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.3
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open project in x64 VSCode that uses Python, run npm install2.
2. error -> gyp ERR! stack Error: Can't find Python executable "C:\Users\---\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36-32", you can set the PYTHO
N env variable.
Python is in the path and exist. though it's 32 bit.
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
